frameDefinitions: A State_of_affairs is generally, or with regard to a particular Feature, representative of its class, which may be narrowed to a specific Comparison_set.
Due to internal forces/properties, an Entity is inclined towards a particular Behavior, which may be to perform an action or to maintain a state.

The adjectives and nouns in this frame are all based on the idea that mental properties may be attributed to a person (Protagonist) by a (usually implicit) Judge  on the basis of that person's Behavior, as broadly understood.
A Protagonist needs a Means action performed for their Benefit.
A certain Idiosyncrasy belongs to an Entity distinguishing it from other entities.
A Cognizer has a piece of Content in their model of the world.
frameExamples: The Elan truly is an <t>unusual</t> car; the first and only Lotus with a front engined/front wheel drive layout, and the first new Lotus to be introduced since 1975.
It was <t>stupid</t> of me to do that.
(1) I <t>rely</t> on you to see that my name is not sullied.
If you have 32 totally <t>idiosyncratic</t> meanings for a term in a class, everyone will be very confused when they talk! DNI
Your boss is <t>aware</t> of your commitment.
listRoleDefinitions: The state of affairs which is evaluated with regard to whether it exhibits the essential characteristics of a Comparison_set.
A property of the <fen>State_of_affairs</fen> wherein it differs or is similar to members of a <fen>Comparison_set</fen>.
TheFrame Element <fen>Entity</fen> identifies the person or thing that has a tendency towards some Behaviour.
The role <fen>Behavior</fen> marks expressions that indicate which state or action the <fen>Entity</fen> tends towards.

This is the person (or people) to whom a mental property is attributed. The role may be expressed as External Argument of a predicative use of the adjective, as a PP Complement, or as the head noun modified by an attributive use of the adjective:

The <fen>Behavior</fen> refers to any action, utterance, belief, or artifact thereof on the basis of which a mental property is attributed to the <fen>Protagonist</fen>. The meaning of the English word <ment>behavior</ment> should not be taken to constrain the identity of this frame element too much---conceptually, this frame element includes things that would not normally be described using the word <ment>behavior</ment>.  Note the following examples:

Some of the words in this frame have a slightly different use in that they evaluate someone only with respect to their mental performance in some particular domain or capacity.  We call this domain or capacity <t>Practice</t>. E.g., She is <t>astute</t> <fex name='Practice'>at math</fex>. Note that this does not mean she is considered to be astute in general for doing math. Rather, she is astute with respect to math, but may be dumb with respect to other things. These uses probably belong in a different frame with words such as <ment>skilled</ment>, but for the time being they are marked with the role Practice. General Grammatical Observations:  The adjectives in this frame may exhibit Extraposition of a <ment>to</ment>-marked infinitive VP, with an optional Protagonist expressed in an <ment>of</ment>-PP: It was <t>brilliant</t> (of you) <fex name='Prac'>to invite the clowns to the party</fex>.
The person or thing whose needs are served by the <fen>Means</fen> action.
An action or state that the <fen>Means</fen> action brings about and from which the <fen>Protagonist</fen> profits.
The person or thing that performs a <fen>Means</fen> action to the <fen>Benefit</fen> of the <fen>Protagonist</fen>.
An object that the <fen>Protagonist</fen> uses to realize a <fen>Benefit</fen>.
An action or state that the <fen>Protagonist</fen> wants to bring about.  It is more or less the <fen>Benefit</fen> viewed in relation to the <fen>Protagonist</fen> rather than the <fen>Means</fen>.
An action performed either by the <fen>Protagonist</fen> or an <fen>Intermediary</fen> that has a <fen>Benefit</fen> for  the <fen>Protagonist</fen> attached to it.
An entity or characteristic  belonging to the <fen>Entity</fen>.
The <fen>Entity</fen> that has a certain distinguishing <fen>Idiosyncrasy</fen>.

The <fen>Cognizer</fen> is the person whose awareness of phenomena is at question. With a target verb or adjective the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is generally expressed as an External Argument with the <fen>Content</fen> expressed as an Object or Complement.
The <fen>Content</fen> is the object of the <fen>Cognizer</fen>'s awareness. <fen>Content</fen> can be expressed as a direct object or in a PP Complement.
Some verbs in this frame allow a <fen>Topic</fen> to be expressed in about-PPs.
<fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part that reveals the <fen>Cognizer</fen>'s state to the observer.
The time interval during which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is aware of the <fen>Content</fen>.
listRoleExamples: However I have always loved having an unusual <fex>name</fex> and I think it's a beautiful name. .
David Hasselhoff's daughters are normal <fex>in every way</fex>.
<fex>Lubomir</fex> was not inclined to believe me
Martha has a tendency <fex>to overdo the housekeeping</fex>.
<fex>You</fex> were smart to save all your receipts.
<fex>I</fex> rely on this walking stick to get me around
He still relies on me <fex>to do the head work</fex>
We rely <fex>on you</fex> for feedback and input
I hate having to rely <fex>on my car</fex> to get where I want to go
The user will quickly begin to rely on the pills <fex>to cope with life pressures</fex>.
Paul has an idiosyncratic <fex>tendency to go barefoot at all times</fex>.
<fex>Your boss</fex> is aware of your commitment.
Your boss is aware <fex>of your commitment</fex>.

Yet there is no evidence that Mr. Parrish was cognizant <fex>at the time of the signing
of the notes</fex> that the clauses in issue were present.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: The Official Rules of Ice Hockey
